abstract: John A. Thain is seeking to leave behind the controversies that haunted his final days at Merrill after it was acquired by Bank of America.
snippet: John A. Thain is seeking to leave behind the controversies that haunted his final days at Merrill after it was acquired by Bank of America.
lead_paragraph: Over his 30-year career, John A. Thain has risen to top executive positions at Goldman Sachs, the New York Stock Exchange and Merrill Lynch.

headline.main: After Turmoil at Merrill, Thain Will Lead the Lender CIT
headline.print_headline: After Turmoil at Merrill, Thain Will Lead the Lender CIT

byline.original: By Michael J. de la Merced

abstract: John A. Thain, the former chief executive of the New York Stock Exchange and Merrill Lynch, on Monday will start over at a humbler institution: the CIT Group, the lender to small and midsize businesses that emerged two months ago from a swift bankruptcy.
snippet: John A. Thain, the former chief executive of the New York Stock Exchange and Merrill Lynch, on Monday will start over at a humbler institution: the CIT Group, the lender to small and midsize businesses that emerged two months ago from a swift bank...
lead_paragraph: Update | 7:32 a.m. Over his 30-year career, John A. Thain has risen to top executive positions at Goldman Sachs, the New York Stock Exchange and Merrill Lynch.

headline.main: After Turmoil at Merrill, Thain Will Lead CIT

abstract: Flush with cash despite the global economic downturn, China’s sovereign wealth fund quietly snapped up more than $9 billion worth of shares last year in some of the biggest American corporations, including Morgan Stanley, Bank of America and Citigroup.
snippet: Flush with cash despite the global economic downturn, China’s sovereign wealth fund quietly snapped up more than $9 billion worth of shares last year in some of the biggest American corporations, including Morgan Stanley, Bank of America and Citig...
lead_paragraph: Flush with cash despite the global economic downturn, China’s sovereign wealth fund quietly snapped up more than $9 billion worth of shares last year in some of the biggest American corporations, including Morgan Stanley, Bank of America and Citigroup.

headline.main: Buying Spree Nets China Stakes in Top U.S. Firms

abstract: A federal judge put a Securities and Exchange Commission lawyer on the defensive on Monday afternoon over a settlement resolving civil charges that accused Bank of America of misleading investors when it acquired Merrill Lynch.
snippet: A federal judge put a Securities and Exchange Commission lawyer on the defensive on Monday afternoon over a settlement resolving civil charges that accused Bank of America of misleading investors when it acquired Merrill Lynch.
lead_paragraph: Update | 4:31 p.m. A federal judge put a lawyer for the Securities and Exchange Commission on the defensive on Monday afternoon over a $150 million settlement resolving the S.E.C.’s civil charges that accused Bank of America of misleading investors when it acquired Merrill Lynch.

headline.main: Judge Presses S.E.C. on BofA Settlement
